paragraphs.text: Do we really need to cancel Christmas?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: It's wonderful (and a good thing) to see the new emphasis on"giving over receiving" at Christmas time
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It's become a trend this year with so many families
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because as parents we want to teach kids about generosity
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Moms and dads everywhere are using Christmas as an opportunity to get their kids thinking about serving others and giving to the less fortunate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: rather than encouraging them to create monstrous Christmas lists describing all the things they want this season
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Some parents are even "cancelling" Christmas for their kids, not giving any family members any gifts
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: do we really need to cancel Christmas in order to foster a spirit of generosity in our kids?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Wednesday I joined Lisa Henderson on "Fox & Friends" to debate this very question
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Lisa has "cancelled Christmas" in her Utah home
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: because
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: she says, her kids have become too entitled,"acting so ungrateful" and "extremely disrespectful."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: So there will be no presents for Christmas
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: as she writes on her blog Overthebigmooon.com,"There is a good possibility that Santa will be writing them a letter of how proud of them he is and perhaps put a few pieces of hard candy and an orange in their stockings."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: While I have great respect for what Lisa wants to accomplish
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I disagree with her approach
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Christmas should begin, not end, at home
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We are already under immense pressure to purge Christmas from our culture
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: First nativity scenes in public places were under attack, now it's Christmas trees
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even saying"Merry Christmas" has taken a back seat to "Happy Holidays."
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cancelling Christmas and using letters from Santa to motivate our kids to be generous is not the answer
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The answer is in putting the emphasis on the miracle not the material
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And here's the good news
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even our gift giving can point to the miracle
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So, yes, we give a few gifts to our kids
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But we also give many gifts to the less fortunate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For example
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we've taught our own kids that the gifts we give them at Christmas aren't based on whether they've been bad or good all year
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The gifts we give them are free, unearned, underserved gifts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: just like the gift of Jesus is a free, unearned, and underserved gift
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This is a very tangible, concrete concept for kids to grasp
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when we serve and give to others, we teach our kids what Jesus said in Matthew 25:40
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "Whatever you do for the least of your brothers and sisters, you do for me."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: So we give gifts to Jesus on his "birthday" by serving and loving and giving to others!
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This is how parents can infuse real meaning into Christmas -- not by refusing to celebrate it all together
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cancelling Christmas is simply not the key to fostering generosity in our kids
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The key to fostering generosity in our kids is by making giving something we do all year round. By making it a lifestyle
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And a lifestyle of giving springs from a deep well of gratitude for how Jesus first gave his life for us
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We have to be so careful not to teach our kids that Christmas is about doing more, trying harder, and being better to be worthy of gifts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Christmas is about anticipating and celebrating the greatest gift that has already been given-- the unconditional love of God in the birth of Jesus Christ
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Our focus shouldn't be on whether or not we have a tree overflowing with gifts, but on whether we have a home overflowing with love
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: His love
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that's our starting place
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: we have a pretty good shot at getting Christmas, and all the 364 other days of the year, right
paragraphs.label: assumption
